Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> from the HashAltCoin discord (makers of F1) #mining: ```
dukeletoToday at 1:34 PM
if VRSC changed their algo, slightly, but kept HarakaV2 core, how long would it take for new private bitstreams to be created, roughly?
just looking for a rough estimate
GEBuckyToday at 1:38 PM
Less than a week if someone put their mind to it.
There are other coins to mine and new algos coming so not the end of the world. .Just very disappointing if it happens.```

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> less than a week to update a trivial bitstream update

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that is not a problem. if we come to an agreement, they would hopefully be able to have a bitstream by activation time for the new algo, and it should then help maintain the interest of casual and even CPU mining with the current thinking by making lowering their relative advantage. if we don't make an agreement, those machines will need to be pointed at other coins, but we will likely have another similar event in the future with unknown options to solve right now. if we make an agreement, FPGA owners would really have nothing to complain about, and miners with CPUs and GPUs would be in a better position to choose Verus as a coin to mine with their hashrate. that is the goal

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> there is no bitstream that those machines would be able get that would enable them to mine the new algorithm if we fully fork away. the problem will be a question of who's next and how much resources will we have to spend next time.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> with no agreement, somebody makes a private bitstream a few weeks later and then an even smaller set of miners have an advantage over the rest of the network

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> the cost on the verus community is very high to constantly fork. I see it as a large issue, as a verus CPU miner, who has been here from almost the genblock

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> not sure what you're saying. can you explain what you mean? the scenario makes no sense to me as I understand it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> Their discord seems to think an agreement is not viable, let's say that fails

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> Verus has the only option to fork, let's call it verushash v2

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> the new private bitstream for that will take a very short time to make, and those people will not release it in a cheap consumer-friendly fpga, most likely

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the reason their discord doesn't like it now is FUD, IMO a big factor here as well, not necessarily intentional, but amplified sometimes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> how will someone make a private bitstream for an algo that can't run on those FPGAs?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> so for verus to fork, fixes the problem for a short time, and makes the problem worse, it seems. But obviously, a lot is being talked about behind closed doors

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> or do you mean a new company with more expensive FPGAs?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> @miketout are you planning on completely changing and not using harakav2? that will take them longer

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> i am talking about people that can make new bitstreams very fast. They say 1 week if you keep haraka v2. Obviously more time if you drastically change it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> how viable is it to drastically change the PoW every X months?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i am not going to say how we will change it until we have an agreement, but i expect to use a Haraka core. suffice it to say, i believe we can up the bar over what they can do now or attenuate them to some degree to enable casual mining with CPUs and likely GPUs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> it can be done, but i believe there are much better things to spend resources on if we can get an agreement that works for everyone

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> an agreement doesn't stop other companies from doing this, or wealthy individuals

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> seems like a rough stopgap, but maybe better than nothing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> an agreement would put an end to fighting hardware, and anyone who does the same will have to deal with the same technical challenge that will not be a stopgap in any case. seems like FUD to me

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> @miketout what exactly is "FUD"?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> fear, uncertainty and doubt

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> i know the definition, what are you saying is FUD?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> to think that there is only a rough stop gap solution

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> or maybe i misunderstood?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> It likely won't be popular opinion but is there a third option of" if you can't beat them join them" by reaching out to all fpga developers and rely on that form  of decentralization to balance them out

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dukeleto> As a CPU miner who was very excited to build a VRSC very power efficient CPU mining farm, all this news made me feel deep dread and stopped all my plans. As a hodler of lots of timelocked VRSC, and a miner, I hope you solve all the problems of FPGAs. But I won't believe it until I see it. The burden of proof is on Verus to show it can protect itself against FPGAs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> It wouldn't make the core miners happy though but it would at least provide a very strong hashrate security and re-establish some form of decentralization that Embraces what we cannot change about the future
